critique: This document is an executive order from 1932 exempting William Bertrand Acker, Chief Clerk, Department of the Interior, from mandatory retirement. Given the historical context of the Great Depression, extending employment could be seen as a slight interventionist measure to support individuals during economic hardship. However, the document itself is very specific and doesn't broadly regulate the economy. It doesn't touch on immigration, federalism, national security, or social inclusion. The extension of executive power is minimal, as it's a specific exemption based on existing legislation.
